bibl.title: Letter from G. Jameson Carr to Henry Rose Carter, June 16, 1924

div1.p: Carr describes the breeding of Aedes aegypti mosquitos in mud puddles in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from G. Jameson Carr to Henry Rose Carter, June 16, 1924
div1.opener:
DEPARTAMENTO DE SAUDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
PARAHYBA DO NORTE--BRASIL
JUNE 16th. 1924.
PRAÇA 1817 N.o 181
CAIXA POSTAL, N.o 41
SIR.
div1.p:
I HAVE THE HONOUR TO SUBMIT THAT SINCE COMMUNICATING TO YOU MY OBSERVATION
ON FORCED AEDES AEGYPTI BREEDING IN MUD PUDDLES I HAVE NOTICED THE FOLLOWING,
WHICH MAY BE OF INTEREST TO YOU.

IN THIS COUNTRY THE POORER CLASSES MAKE THEIR HOUSES OUT OF POLES LASHED
TOGETHER AND PLASTERED WITH MUD, WHICH THEY DIG OUT OF THE EARTH USUALLY
A FEW YARDS AWAY FROM THE BUILDING, WHICH LEAVES A HOLE LIKE THE BEGINNING
OF A WELL AND WHICH SERVES AFTERWARDS AS A REFUSE DUMP.

ONE OF THESE I CAME ACROSS ON JUNE 1st FOUR FEET DEEP WITH STRAIGHT EARTH
SIDES AND CONTAINING 1 FOOT OF RAIN WATER.

THERE WAS NO DEBRIS IN THE WATER WHICH WAS MUDDY, AND FROM WHICH I PROCURED
LARVAE, WHICH ON BREEDING OUT GAVE 13 CULEX FATIGANS, 2 MALE AND 3 FEMALE
AEDES AEGYPTI AND 2 MALE A. NUMBUS (THEOBALD). THE WATER HAD A Ph OF 7.
THE NEGRO WHOSE SHACK IT WAS, TOLD ME THAT THE HOLE HAD BEEN DUG A YEAR
BEFORE AND THAT IT ONLY HAD HAD WATER SINCE THE FIRST OF MAY, AND VARIED
IN DEPTH ACCORDING TO THE RAINS.

THE DISTANCE FROM THE HOUSE WAS 7 YARDS, AND THERE WAS NO OTHER WATER NEARER
THAN 30 YARDS, WHICH WAS OVER A HEDGE IN A NEIGHBOURS YARD, HE ONLY SLEEPING IN
THE HOUSE, AND DOING NO COOKING AND, FROM HIS APPEARANCE NO WASHING.

I ALSO GOT AEDES AEGYPTI OVAE FROM THE EARTH SIDES 3in. ABOVE THE WATER
FROM WHICH I BRED 4 MALES AND 1 FEMALE.

ALTHOUGH THIS IS NOT A TECHNICAL MUD PUDDLE IT FULFILLS SOME OF THE
CONDITIONS OF A MUD PUDDLE AND APPEARS TO INDICATE THAT THE AEDES AEGYPTI
WILL BREED UNDER THOSE CONDITIONS IF NO OTHER WATER IS NEAR.

DEPARTAMENTO DE SAUDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
PARAHYBA DO NORTE--BRASIL

THE WATER IN WHICH I BRED THE LARVAE AND OVAE WAS THE SAME WATER IN WHICH I
FOUND THEM, AND HAD A TEMPERATURE OF 25 CENTIGRADE.

THE TYPE OF EARTH IS A SANDY DARK RED CLAY AND THE SIDES WERE PACKED HARD.
MAY I ASK IF IT HAS BEEN NOTICED BEFORE THAT, ON BREEDING OUT FROM EGGS, THAT
THERE IS NOT ONLY A CONSTANT PREPONDERENCE OF MALES, BUT ALSO THAT THE FIRST
ADULTS ARE ALWAYS MALES?. MUCH LITERATURE IS NOT AVAILABLE HERE, BUT I THINK THAT
THIS MAY HAVE A BEARING ON THE QUESTION OF THE CESSATION OF YELLOW FEVER AFTER
A CERTAIN INDEX IS REACHED, IN TERMS OF THE LAW OF CHANCE.

I HAVE THE HONOUR TO BE
SIR
div1.closer:
YOUR OBEDIENT SERVANT G. Jamson Carr
Director. ASSISTANT SURGEON GENERAL
H. R. CARTER MD.
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
WASHINGTON D.C. U.S.A.
